pullRequest.body:
Formalize IMO 2024 Q6.


---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Aquaesulian.apply_apply_add`
`+ Aquaesulian.apply_neg_apply`
`+ Aquaesulian.apply_neg_apply_add`
`+ Aquaesulian.apply_neg_apply_neg`
`+ Aquaesulian.apply_neg_eq_neg_iff`
`+ Aquaesulian.apply_neg_of_apply_eq`
`+ Aquaesulian.apply_zero`

`+ Aquaesulian.injective`

`+ Aquaesulian.u_eq_zero_or_v_eq_zero`

`+ aquaesulian_fExample`

`+ fExample`
`+ fExample_add`
`+ fExample_int_add`
`+ fExample_of_mem_Ico`
`+ floor_fExample`
`+ fract_fExample`
`++ Aquaesulian`
`++ Aquaesulian.card_le_two`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10021507022/job/27700258145)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10021507022/job/27700258324)

The lean code looks fine to me.

maintainer merge

The lean code looks fine to me.

maintainer merge

The official question is to prove that "there exist an integer such that...", so you should write a Lean statement as close as possible to that. In particular I don't think we need `answer`.

Also, you don't prove that `2` is the smallest possible `c`, don't you?
Here you are mixing LaTeX with unicode: can you stick with one of them? I think unicode is fine.
Changed to use Unicode more consistently.
I think the final result is usually called something like `_root_.imo2024q6`
Renamed as suggested.
This and the next two lemmas could be `simp`, and maybe some of the later proofs simplify.
Made three lemmas simp lemmas, simplified one proof.
Does `abel` work here?
It produces a suggestion to use `abel_nf`, so I used `abel_nf` to avoid that message.
Do we really need this?
Proving that 2 is the smallest possible c is part of the problem and requires showing the existence of such a function, and this example is used in that proof.
OK, let's keep it then. But I think we should explicitly write a statement that show that `2` is the smallest answer.

That's what the two parts of the stated result are intended to cover: for all such functions the range has cardinality at most `answer` (i.e. 2) and there exists a function where it has cardinality exactly `answer`. There are of course many possible equivalent ways to state this (including embedding the value of `answer` directly in the statement if you want something more idiomatic as a Lean statement and less directly showing exactly what was expected in the original problem - but if you're going for maximally idiomatic Lean, you'd normally have two theorems rather than one theorem with an `âˆ§`).
I'm fine with the `âˆ§`, but I really don't see the point of using `answer`. For the second part, I read the question as: `âˆ€ c, #{....} â‰¤ c â†’ 2 â‰¤ c`.
I've adjusted it to inline `2` and to say `âˆ€ c : â„•, (âˆ€ f, Aquaesulian f â†’ #(Set.range (fun x â†¦ f x + f (-x))) â‰¤ c) â†’ 2 â‰¤ c` for the second part.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Archive/Imo): IMO 2024 Q6
